title: Can people with average IQs enjoy playing musical instruments (trumpets, trombone, etc.)? - Quora

response.answer_text: IQ measuring is still a quackery. Most so-called “IQ tests” measure your level of education, your general knowledge, your spatial vision instead of your intelligence. We don’t even have an unimpeachable definition for intelligence. People who lack the interest to learn certain things will score as low on these tests as people who lack the ability to learn them. I know doctors and street-sweepers who love music and play an instrument, and I know qualified musicians, playing in a symphonic orchestra, who never liked music, and play it just because they are too lazy to learn any other trade. I know a “former” musician who sold his instruments and became a taxi driver, and one who really learned something new and became an electrician. Thirty years ago I played for about a year in a Romanian Gypsy band. I was the only non-Gypsy among them, accepted because I taught them the basics of music notation, some even how to write their own names.Translation: the love of music an the desire to play is totally independent of our current definition of intelligence OR education. It’s also independent of the color of your skin, hair or eyes, your height and width, sexual orientation or religion. And if you lack the ability to learn numbers and names (who cares about history, anyway?), your brain might even “compensate” this with extraordinary musical talent. P.S. Talent is not enough. You still have to want AND do something (learn, practice, learn, practice and so on) to be able to play.

Yes, absolutely. Each person who learns an instrument will eventually find their niche where they fit right in. Admittedly many of the most accomplished players are highly intelligent, but for the rest of us, we can still derive much pleasure from learning and playing an instrument. A couple of things to bear in mind though: if a child is in fact mentally challenged (as opposed to just average intelligence) then finding the right teacher and the right instrument is very important. E.g. the child may have a strong sense of rhythm but a poorly developed sense of melody. Then trumpet would not be the best instrument. Drums would be a better fit. Also, watch for signs that the child is really not enjoying learning an instrument - there's no point in forcing something that isn't a good match. Thirdly, specialized individual music tuition is not music therapy. Music therapy is conducted by psychologists who use music as a tool to help people function better. Music lessons are conducted by musicians who use various instrumental teaching methods to help people play better. Regular practicing sharpens the brain, but lessons in and of themselves aren't any more stimulating than say, a Sodoku puzzle.

If you have an average IQ, some might think that you might have to lower it to enjoy playing instruments even more. Using a hammer against one’s head on the third beat, every other measure in 4/4 time won’t help. Nor do any of the other drastic things suggested in The Rolling Stones’ “(I Know) It’s Only Rock and Roll” (pen, knife in my heart, & etc.). You’ve got to “like it” to play it and enjoy it more. I think there is something to be gained by parents’/guardians’ forcing the early introduction of an instrument upon a child of learning-age. It may pass a shared skill from generation to generation in the family. A duet by a parent and child sharing a piano bench can be fun, like the two playing a song on a couple guitars. Music also has been shown to help the brain develop in surprising ways that other learning doesn’t. I know that that’s not IQ, but it does help the brain grow. See some search results at this page: https://scholar.google.ca/scholar?q=music+brain+development&hl=en&as_sdt=0&as_vis=1&oi=scholart If guardians don’t help or push when one is younger, but that younger one still thinks of music “… I like it,” then have at it. Take jobs, save your allowance, borrow an instrument from the band-class at school, place an ad seeking an unused instrument people might have in a closet or under a bed (help them “down-size”), then take some lessons. Learn some theory that will apply to more than one instrument. Seek a music club where you can play a variety of styles. I hope you enjoy playing your instruments.

I have to say that IQ is not a concept I in any way agree with (I have a degree in Psychology and many years experience in education) and it has nothing to do with being able to play a musical instrument. IQ is about solving silly little puzzles. It has little, if any relevance to daily reality. Music calls into play lots of different brain functions and has a very positive effect on general functioning. This is one reason Music Therapy is being developed more and more, for all sorts of conditions, including dementia and PTSD. Playing music can be a really joyful experience - in fact, if it isn’t joyful for you, don’t do it! I’d recommend anybody to try. Tone deafness is a real thing but is a very, very rare physical condition. Anybody can do something, even if it’s shake a tambourine or bang some hand drums.

I have a below average IQ (75) and I love music. It's kept me alive through hell and back in my life. Through an abusive parental relationship to dealing with PTSD. What turned into a life saving coping skill came out a love in music. I sing and I play some guitar. I'm into Alternative rock and pretty much any rock genre. But, I've heard of a guy from Japan who's an autistic savant with an IQ of 50 who's a progidy in percussion. Anybody can be musically inclined in my opinion it's just up to you the individual to try it. For some it will work others it won't. But I'm going to be attending hopefully a music apprenticeship next year. I hope I get in because music is a big part of my life and I've grown up in a house where it's not looked good upon to get involved with it, but I say screw it. Anyways, have a nice one.

They certainly can. In my judgment IQ has little or no bearing on ability to sing or play an instrument - with or without formal training. Maybe music accesses a different part of the brain. I know many good people who are academically undistinguished who are are great musicians, In UK a phenomenon of recent years has been the emergence of ‘community choirs’ and ‘bad orchestras’ with zero qualifications for entry. Many people have huge fun from such groups and most make rather good music. A good, friendly teacher helps! Enjoy your music!

Playing a musical instrument has very little to do with intelligence and a lot to do with patience, persistence and desire. Music theory probably requires more intelligence, but you don’t really need to know any music theory to actually play. It helps if you’re goong to keep improving, but is by no means necessary. Take it from a guy who does it for a living and has only the vaguest concept of music theory. ;-)

Yes. Of course. What you need is: The will to learnConsistent practice (quality over quantity, a lot can be achieved with just 30 minutes a day if done right)A good step by step program (online or in person)Effective and encouraging feedback (from a teacher, peer, mentor)The believe that you can do itResearch has shown that learning a musical instrument has a positive effect on intelligence, similar to learning a language. In any event, go for it! Thanks for A2A

IQ has absolutely nothing to do with playing an instrument. I’ve known some musicians (well drummers actually) who couldn’t spell IQ. It is thought that playing an instrument can actually increase a person’s IQ (unless they’re drummers).
IQ has nothing to do with the enjoyment of playing these instruments….individuals who take up these instruments have been indoctrinated & brainwashed by watching the Music Man too many times.
I do not believe IQ is a determining factor. To learn how to play a musical instrument takes patience and persistence and practice practice practice. I say yes
